pr_title: HBASE-24367 ScheduledChore log elapsed timespan in a human-friendly format

timeline.bodyText: log the start time, too? If the debug was enabled between execution, may get a wrong execution time?
timeline.author: infraio

replies.bodyText: Oh, fun edge case @infraio :) How about a check that start > 0 and only log in that case?
replies.author: ndimiduk

replies.bodyText: Yes we can do that. Will update
replies.author: apurtell

replies.bodyText: I was expecting to find something like if (LOG.isDebugEnabled() && start > 0) { here. Was this comment addressed elsewhere? Thanks.
replies.author: ndimiduk

timeline.bodyText: A question of clarification. I think what you have is correct, but I'm asking anyway. We have EnvironmentEdgeManager, which abstracts a form of clock. System.nanoTime() is a different form of clock. Is there some case where we'd want the nanoTime to be abstracted behind EnvironmentEdgeManager? My understanding is no, we don't have such a use-case, because EnvironmentEdgeManager is for abstracting over a clock-time (a la java.time.Instant), while nanoTime is providing a timer for calculating a time duration, something that is abstract from a clock-time.
timeline.author: ndimiduk

replies.bodyText: We don't, but we could. Would be another scope of change I think.
replies.author: apurtell

replies.bodyText: Yeah I was kind of caviler about the ifdebug guards. Will fix
replies.author: apurtell

replies.bodyText: I'm not asking for a scope change, just clarifying my understanding.
replies.author: ndimiduk

timeline.bodyText: Do we want some duration threshold that triggers escalating the log level to info (or warn), as was done before?
timeline.author: ndimiduk

replies.bodyText: Not opposed to the idea at all, but it's going to depend on the chore, right?
replies.author: apurtell

replies.bodyText: yeah i think you're right. let's leave it for now.
replies.author: ndimiduk
